title: Johann Georg Lickl
text:
Johann Georg Lickl, also Ligkl, Hans-Georg Lickl, (11 April 1769 – 12 May 1843) was an Austrian composer, organist, <a href="Kapellmeister">Kapellmeister</a> in the main church of Pécs, and <a href="piano%20teacher">piano teacher</a>.
Lickl was born in <a href="Korneuburg">Korneuburg</a>, <a href="Lower%20Austria">Lower Austria</a>, and <a href="orphan">orphan</a>ed as a child. He studied under <a href="Witzig">Witzig</a>, who was the organist at the church of Korneuburg.
He relocated to <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a> in 1785 and studied under <a href="Albrechtsberger">Albrechtsberger</a> and <a href="Joseph%20Haydn">Joseph Haydn</a>. Later in the 1780s, he became organist at the <a href="Carmelite">Carmelite</a> church in <a href="Leopoldstadt">Leopoldstadt</a>. He collaborated with <a href="Emanuel%20Schikaneder">Emanuel Schikaneder</a> on a number of "<a href="Singspiele">Singspiele</a>" in the 1790s, working in the <a href="Theater%20auf%20der%20Wieden">Theater auf der Wieden</a>. He died, aged 74, in Fünfkirchen (), southern <a href="History%20of%20Hungary%201700%E2%80%931919">Royal Hungary</a>, <a href="Habsburg%20Monarchy">Imperial Austria</a>.
He wrote operas, one <a href="wind%20quintet">wind quintet</a>, three <a href="string%20quartet">string quartet</a>s, and served as a <a href="Kapellmeister">Kapellmeister</a> at several churches. From 1807 until his death he was choirmaster at what is now <a href="P%C3%A9cs">Pécs</a>.
A large portion of his output is sacred music, including <a href="mass%20%28music%29">mass</a>es and <a href="requiem">requiem</a>s.
In 1843, some of his piano- and chamber music works were published by <a href="Tobias%20Haslinger">Tobias Haslinger</a> (Vienna), <a href="Johann%20Anton%20Andr%C3%A9">Johann Anton André</a> (Offenbach) and (Augsburg).
His sons, Karl Georg Lickl (1801, Vienna – 1877, Vienna) and Ägid(ius Ferdinand) Karl Lickl (1803, Vienna – 1864, Trieste), were also composers, whose output includes works for piano and for <a href="physharmonica">physharmonica</a>, including a transcription of <a href="Beethoven">Beethoven</a>'s "<a href="Mass%20in%20C%20major%20%28Beethoven%29">Mass in C major</a>" for physharmonica and piano.
